Description: Egyptian mould-made oil-lamp. 'Potato' type. The reservoir has a circular central hole in the top with a ring modelled around it, and three raised bosses around that. The nozzle projects a short way from the body, and is decorated with a thin rim. Dark soot discolouration around the nozzle, likely caused by use. Beige-brown clay.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Nottingham Castle Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

So-called potato lamp with 3 bosses. Parallels found in end of the 1st to mid second century AD contexts at Mons Claudianus (Knowles 2006, MC X45-50, type C2.1b). Bailey previously dated these to the 3rd or 4th century AD. Knowles, K. 2006. The pottery lamps. In V.A.Maxfield and D.P.S. Peacock Survey and excavation at Mons Claudianus 1987-1993. Vol.3 Ceramic vessels and related objects. IFAO Cairo. 309–426.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.48) (Phase 3)
